games.title: Wayward Queen Attack: Scholar’s Mate Theme
games.description: Two lines starting from the same early queen sortie. Side A shows what happens when Black ignores king safety. Side B shows a simple, principled defense that neutralizes the threat and reaches a comfortable position.

A.label: Side A (Attack succeeds quickly)
A.pgn: 1. e4 e5 2. Qh5 Nc6 3. Bc4 Nf6?? 4. Qxf7#

annotations.text: White claims central space and opens lines for the bishop and queen. This is the foundation for rapid development and early initiative.
Black mirrors central control. Both sides now have open lines, which makes king safety and development especially urgent.
White immediately eyes f7, the weakest point in Black’s starting position. This is playable but risks wasting time with the queen.
Black develops while covering key squares. This also attacks the queen’s route and prepares to contest the center.
White completes the classic battery on f7: queen + bishop. The threat is now extremely concrete.
This develops, but it fails to address the immediate mate threat. Development is not useful if it allows forced mate.
Mate. The king cannot capture because the bishop on c4 protects f7, and the king has no legal escape squares.

phases.name: Opening
phases.overview: A fast tactical finish. The key lesson is that king safety and immediate threats override 'normal development'.

B.label: Side B (Defense succeeds; attacker loses momentum)
B.pgn: 1. e4 e5 2. Qh5 Nc6 3. Bc4 g6 4. Qf3 Nf6 5. Ne2 Bg7 6. d3 O-O 7. O-O d6 8. h3 Be6 9. Bg5 Bxc4 10. dxc4 h6 11. Bxf6 Qxf6 12. Qxf6 Bxf6

annotations.text: A sound central claim. Even when tactics appear early, strong openings start with center control and development.
Black meets the center directly. This keeps options flexible and supports rapid piece activity.
White targets f7. The strategic risk: the queen can become a tempo target, and White may fall behind in development.
Develop and hit the queen’s idea indirectly. Black adds control and prepares to defend f7 efficiently.
The battery is formed. Black must respond precisely to f7 pressure.
This calmly breaks the battery by challenging the queen’s line and preparing Bg7. It is a common, principled defense.
White keeps the idea alive, but continuing to ‘chase the mate’ often costs tempi that Black converts into development.
Now this development move is safe and effective because the mate threat has been defused.
This is playable, but White is choosing slower routes after already spending time with the queen.
Black completes a key defensive setup: the king will castle and the bishop will pressure central squares.
White solidifies the center, but the position is already drifting away from a direct attack. White must now ‘play chess’ rather than hunt mate.
Black castles. The strategic message: defend first, then develop, then seek advantage.
White castles to catch up. This is often what happens after an over-ambitious opening: you must spend moves repairing structure and safety.
Black supports e5 and prepares ...Be6 to challenge White’s bishop and reduce attacking potential.
A small luft/prophylaxis move, but it’s another tempo spent on the flank. In openings, tempi matter.
Black contests the active bishop. This is a typical plan: trade off your opponent’s most dangerous piece and emerge with easier play.
White seeks activity. However, the original attack is gone, and now Black has comfortable development and a clear plan.
Black exchanges a key attacker and simplifies into a position where White’s early queen adventure yields no lasting gain.
White recaptures but accepts structural compromises. This is a common ‘cost’ when you chase early tactics and then get forced into reactive moves.
Black asks the bishop to decide. This is a thematic way to dissolve pins and gain space.
White gives up the bishop to avoid retreat. The net result is that Black reaches a simplified position with straightforward play.
Black’s queen becomes active. Importantly, Black has no king danger anymore and can start thinking about central breaks and endgame edges.
White chooses a queen trade to reduce pressure. This is often the practical choice when the initiative is gone.
Black recaptures with a piece, completing a favorable simplification. In an MVP, we treat this as ‘strategy succeeds’ for Black: defend accurately, develop, simplify.

phases.name: Opening
phases.overview: Neutralize the immediate threat (…g6), then complete development and castle. The attacker’s initiative fades.

phases.name: Middlegame
phases.overview: Convert the attacker’s lost tempi into concrete actions: challenge active pieces (…Be6), simplify, and improve piece coordination.

phases.name: Endgame
phases.overview: Simplify into an endgame where the defender’s structure and development lead to comfortable play.

games.title: King’s Pawn Principles: Fast Development vs Slow Tempi
games.description: A longer, principles-oriented example designed for the Phases page. Side A follows basic development principles and wins material. Side B shows how slow, non-developing moves can be punished.

A.label: Side A (Develop quickly; win material)
A.pgn: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. c3 Nf6 5. d4 exd4 6. cxd4 Bb4+ 7. Nc3 Nxe4 8. O-O Bxc3 9. d5 Bf6 10. Re1 Ne7 11. Rxe4 d6 12. Bg5 Bxg5 13. Nxg5 O-O 14. Nxh7 Kxh7 15. Rh4+ Kg8 16. Qh5

annotations.text: White takes space and opens lines for rapid development.
Black matches in the center.
Develop and attack the center (e5). This also prepares castling.
Black develops and defends e5.
White develops with tempo toward the center and kingside.
Black mirrors development, also targeting f2.
White prepares d4 to challenge the center with pawn support.
Black develops and increases pressure on e4.
A thematic strike: open lines when you are developed and ready to use them.
Black captures to resolve central tension.
White recaptures, opening the c-file and keeping central presence.
Black checks and tries to disrupt development.
White blocks the check while developing. This is an ideal response pattern.
Black wins a pawn but may fall behind in safety and coordination.
White castles first—then starts tactical operations with a safe king.
Black trades a bishop to reduce pressure, but concedes the bishop pair.
White pushes with tempo, opening lines and restricting Black’s pieces.
Black must retreat; White’s initiative is doing work.
White places a rook on the e-file to pressure e4 and the center.
Black tries to consolidate, but space and tempo favor White.
White wins back the pawn and keeps initiative. In a principles demo, this is the ‘conversion’ moment.
Black tries to stabilize the center and open lines for development.
White develops and creates concrete pressure on f6/e7 structures.
Black trades to reduce threats.
White recaptures with a piece that can jump into tactics.
Black finally castles, but White is already dictating the pace.
A thematic raid to open lines. For training, the emphasis is initiative enabled by development.
Black accepts; the king is drawn into danger.
White brings a rook into the attack with tempo.
Black tries to return to safety.
White’s pieces coordinate against the king. Lesson: development enables attack.

phases.name: Opening
phases.overview: Develop pieces, contest the center, and castle. Block checks while developing (Nc3) as a key habit.

phases.name: Middlegame
phases.overview: Use space and tempo to win back material and improve piece activity. Put rooks on files and force concessions.

phases.name: Endgame
phases.overview: Not a true endgame—treat as ‘late middlegame / king attack’ in the UI if desired.

B.label: Side B (Slow moves; lose initiative and comfort)
B.pgn: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. h3 Nf6 5. d3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. c3 h6 8. Re1 a6 9. Nbd2 Be6 10. Bb3 Re8 11. Nf1 d5 12. exd5 Nxd5

annotations.text: White starts correctly with central space.
Black matches in the center.
Develop and influence the center.
Black develops.
White develops actively.
Black mirrors development.
A slow, non-developing move in an open game. Early tempi are precious; prioritize development and central play.
Black continues developing and prepares to castle.
Solid but passive compared to d4. Combined with h3, White is conceding initiative.
Black chooses a stable structure and keeps options open.
White castles, but earlier slow moves mean Black will be comfortable.
Black castles and reaches easy equality with good piece placement.
White prepares d4, but doing it late reduces its effect.
With no pressure, Black can improve slowly and prevent ideas.
Rook to the e-file is correct, but White ceded initiative earlier.
Black gains flexibility without tactical risk.
White develops, but Black already has a comfortable plan.
Black develops with tempo, preparing central breaks.
White retreats; Black’s plan is easier to execute.
Black aligns rooks and prepares …d5.
Slow maneuvering while Black is ready to strike the center.
Black seizes the moment to open lines—punishing White’s earlier slow moves.
White must react; Black’s pieces gain active targets.
Knight centralizes with tempo. In the MVP, this represents the strategic ‘win’: better timing, more active play.

phases.name: Opening
phases.overview: Avoid slow pawn moves (like h3) without concrete purpose. Develop and castle.

phases.name: Middlegame
phases.overview: Once development is complete, strike the center (…d5). Slow maneuvering is punished by central breaks.
